sections.content: Programs need to make decisions. If statements let your code choose different paths based on conditions. Like a fork in the road: if condition is True, go this way; otherwise, go that way. This is foundation of program logic and enables dynamic, intelligent behavior.

sections.title: Basic If Statement
items: Indentation required: Code inside if must be indented
Condition must be True/False: Uses comparison operators
Multiple lines: All indented code runs if True

sections.content: If-else: Handles both cases. If condition True, run first block. If False, run else block. One or the other always runs, never both. Pattern: Check condition, execute appropriate code block.

sections.title: Elif (Multiple Conditions)
items: First True condition runs, rest skipped

sections.content: Nested conditionals: If statements inside if statements. Checks multiple layers of conditions. Use sparingly—deep nesting gets confusing. Alternative: Use 'and' to combine conditions when possible.

sections.title: Practical Examples
items: Age verification: if age >= 21: print('Can drink')
Password check: if password == correct_password: login()
Range check: if 0 <= score <= 100: valid_score = True
Form validation: if len(password) < 8: print('Password too short')

quiz.question: What's required for if statement code?
quiz.explanation: Python uses indentation to define code blocks. Code inside if statement must be indented (usually 4 spaces). No indentation = syntax error.

quiz.question: In if-elif-else, what happens?
options: First True condition runs, rest skipped
quiz.explanation: If-elif-else checks conditions in order. First True runs, rest skipped. If none True, else runs (if present). Only one block executes.

sections.content: Loops repeat code multiple times. While loops repeat AS LONG AS condition is True. Like 'while hungry, keep eating.' Check condition, run code, check again, run again, until condition becomes False. Powerful but dangerous—infinite loops are real!

sections.title: While Loop Basics
items: count += 1  # CRITICAL: Update to eventually become False
Danger: Forget to update → infinite loop!

sections.content: Infinite loops: Loop that never stops. Happens when condition never becomes False. Example: while True: print('Forever!'). Your program hangs. Solution: Ensure condition can become False, or use break statement to exit.

sections.title: Loop Control
items: continue: Skips rest of current iteration, starts next

sections.title: Common While Loop Patterns
items: Counter: count = 0; while count < limit: ... count += 1
User input validation: while invalid_input: get_input()
Accumulator: total = 0; while more_items: total += item
Search: while not_found and more_to_search: check_next()

sections.content: When to use while loops: When you don't know how many iterations needed. Examples: waiting for user input, processing until condition met, game loops, retry logic. If you know iteration count, use for loop (next lesson).

quiz.question: What makes while loop stop?
options: When condition becomes False (or break statement)
quiz.explanation: While loop stops when condition becomes False (or break executes). Critical: ensure condition can become False to avoid infinite loops!

quiz.question: What does break do?
quiz.explanation: break exits loop immediately, regardless of condition. Useful for exit conditions inside loop. continue skips current iteration, continues with next.

sections.content: For loops iterate over sequences. 'For each item in this collection, do something.' Know exactly how many iterations. Safer than while (can't accidentally be infinite). Most common loop type. Master this and you'll write much more efficient code.
Iterating over collections: For loops shine when processing lists, strings, or any sequence. Automatically gets each item. No manual indexing needed. Clean and readable.

sections.title: Iterating Over Data
items: List: for name in names: print(name)

sections.title: Common For Loop Patterns
items: Counting: for i in range(10): total += i
Processing list: for item in items: process(item)
Building list: results = []; for x in data: results.append(transform(x))
Printing table: for row in table: print(row)
String processing: for char in text: if char.isdigit(): count += 1
Nested loops (careful): for i in range(3): for j in range(3): print(i, j)

sections.content: For vs While: Use for when you know iterations (process list, repeat N times). Use while when you don't (wait for condition, user input until valid). For is safer (no infinite loops) and cleaner for definite iteration.

quiz.question: What does range(5) produce?
quiz.explanation: range(5) produces 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 (5 numbers starting at 0). Python uses 0-indexing. To get 1-5, use range(1, 6).

quiz.question: When to use for vs while?
options: For: known iterations; While: unknown iterations (condition-based)
quiz.explanation: For: known iterations (process list, repeat N times). While: unknown iterations (until condition met). For is safer for definite iteration.

sections.content: Functions are reusable code blocks. Instead of writing same code repeatedly, write once as function, use anywhere. Takes inputs (parameters), does something, returns output. Like a machine: put ingredients in, get product out. Functions make code cleaner, more organized, easier to debug.

sections.title: Creating Functions
items: return: Sends value back to caller

sections.content: Parameters vs Arguments: Parameters are variables in function definition. Arguments are actual values passed when calling. Example: def add(a, b) - a and b are parameters. add(3, 5) - 3 and 5 are arguments.

sections.title: Function Parameters
items: One parameter: def square(x): return x ** 2
Multiple: def add(a, b): return a + b
Default values: def greet(name='User'): return f'Hi {name}'
Calling with defaults: greet() returns 'Hi User'
Order matters: Arguments match parameters by position

sections.title: Return Values
items: Multiple returns: return x, y (returns tuple)
Early return: return exits function immediately
Print vs return: print displays, return sends value

sections.content: Why use functions: DRY principle (Don't Repeat Yourself). Write logic once, reuse everywhere. Changes in one place apply everywhere. Easier testing. Better organization. Enables collaboration. Professional code heavily uses functions.

sections.title: Practical Examples
items: return '@' in email and '.' in email

quiz.question: What does return do?
options: Sends value back to caller and exits function
quiz.explanation: return sends value back to caller and exits function. Without return, function returns None. Print displays; return provides value.

quiz.question: What's a parameter vs argument?
options: Parameter: variable in definition; Argument: actual value when calling
quiz.explanation: Parameter: variable in function definition (def func(x)). Argument: actual value passed when calling (func(5)). x is parameter, 5 is argument.

sections.content: Beyond basics: scope, lambda functions, and function best practices. These concepts separate beginner from intermediate Python. Understanding scope prevents bugs. Lambda functions enable concise code. Best practices make your functions professional-grade.

sections.title: Variable Scope
items: Local: Variables inside function, only accessible inside
Global: Variables outside functions, accessible everywhere
print(y)  # ERROR: y doesn't exist outside func
Best practice: Minimize global variables, use parameters

sections.content: Lambda functions: Small anonymous functions. One-line, no name needed. Syntax: lambda parameters: expression. Use for simple operations. Example: double = lambda x: x * 2. Often used with map, filter, sorted.

sections.title: Lambda Functions
items: Multiple args: add = lambda a, b: a + b
Use with sorted: sorted(names, key=lambda x: len(x))
Use with map: list(map(lambda x: x * 2, numbers))
Use with filter: list(filter(lambda x: x > 0, numbers))
When to use: Simple, one-line operations
When not: Complex logic (use regular function)

sections.title: Function Best Practices
items: One task: Each function does one thing well
Short: If too long, split into smaller functions
Avoid side effects: Don't modify global state
Return, don't print: Return values, let caller print if needed
Consistent: Similar functions should work similarly

sections.content: Docstrings: Documentation inside function. First line after def. Triple quotes. Explains what function does, parameters, and return value. Example: def add(a, b): '''Add two numbers and return result''' return a + b

sections.title: Common Function Patterns
items: Transformer: Takes input, returns modified version
Calculator: Takes inputs, returns computed value
def calculate_interest(principal, rate, time): return principal * rate * time
Generator: Creates and returns new data
def create_user(name, email): return {'name': name, 'email': email}

quiz.question: What's variable scope?
options: Where variable can be accessed (local inside function, global everywhere)
quiz.explanation: Scope determines where variable can be accessed. Local: inside function only. Global: everywhere. Variables inside function can't be accessed outside.

quiz.question: When to use lambda functions?
options: For simple, one-line operations (especially with map, filter, sorted)
quiz.explanation: Lambda for simple, one-line operations, often with map/filter/sorted. For complex logic, use regular function with proper name and documentation.
